ygData.msgSnippet: Thanks for the kind words Nicolas. It is true that Avida explicitly checks whether certain metabolic functions are performed, but (as you mention) performing

Thanks for the kind words Nicolas. 

It is true that Avida explicitly check=
s whether certain metabolic functions are performed, but (as you mention) p=
erforming such functions only speeds up the replication of a given Avidian =
(and there are other ways Avidians can speed up replication, such as improv=
ing their self-replication speed). So, I agree that Avida has injected some=
 target-based search (though for multiple, different targets), moving it a =
bit away from Tierra and towards traditional EAs. 

However, I think the mo=
re provocative question is this: why does it matter if the fitness function=
 is implicit or explicit? We know that in Tierra and Avida, replication spe=
ed is the ultimate fitness function, and various things can speed up or slo=
w down replication. Why is that interestingly different from target-based s=
earch? There are many who believe that Tierra and Avida represent a fundame=
ntally different type of system because they don't have an "explicit fitnes=
s function", but I've never really understood why they are fundamentally di=
fferent in an interesting way. Is the main difference that there are many d=
ifferent ways to accomplish the overarching goal? If so, why isn't that als=
o true in most target-based objectives? For example, when evolving gaits fo=
r legged robots (an example of what is called an explicit fitness function/=
target-based search), there are many different ways to achieve higher veloc=
ities. 

I agree that open-ended evolution is more likely to occur when the=
re are many different, rewarded ways to survive=85so I do agree that more a=
bstract goals (such as replication speed) that can be solved in different w=
ays are less likely to get stuck on local optima, but there are many differ=
ent ways to solve most target-based problems, and I don't see why these non=
-explicit fitness function systems have that many more ways than explicit f=
itness functions. Novelty search, on the other hand, really seems to open t=
hings up and be a fundamental game changer, which is why I see it as fundam=
entally different and extremely interesting. 

Best regards,
Jeff Clune

Vi=
siting Scientist
Cornell University
jeffclune@...
jeffclune.com

On=
 Oct 10, 2012, at 6:33 PM, Nicolas Bredeche <nekonaute@...> wrote:

> =

> Hi, 
> 
> I understand that this short discussion about target-based vs.=
 non-target-based evolution may grow a bit off-topic, but I would love to t=
ake this discussion a little further about the difference btw objective-dri=
ven and environment-driven evolution.
> 
> (...)
> > I'm also not sure whet=
her it's really accurate to say Avida is "not target-based." It's true that=
 it's not as explicit as a single simple objective function, but the fact t=
hat there are several logical operations that explicitly give an advantage =
to organisms that execute them actually does create a form of objective-dri=
ven pressure. In other words, the creativity of evolution in Avida with suc=
h a priori human-defined rewards is to some extent hampered by the need to =
stay competitive on those arbitrary objectives. So I'd expect it to be clos=
er to objective search (when used in that mode) than non-objective search, =
though somewhere on the continuum between them. I also understand that Avid=
a as a platform doesn't have to be run with those rewards, but if I underst=
and correctly they are traditional and used in this particular paper as wel=
l.
> >
> 
> I agree with you. Avida is likely more towards non-objective se=
arch than target-based search, but probably not by that much. You'd likely =
get a stronger argument from Charles Ofria about it being more open-ended, =
but I've always thought that Avida (and all alife simulations) are still ra=
ther target-based. That's why I don't put too much stock in the argument th=
at not having an explicit fitness function makes some alife simulations mor=
e interesting: I usually think they do have an explicit fitness function, i=
t's just a complicated one that we don't understand as much as others.
>  (=
...)
> 
> It seems to me that one additional property must be taken into ac=
count about how the selection pressure is actually applied. On the one hand=
, selection can be implemented as an user-defined metric used to compare an=
d rank individuals for selection/replacement, which is the classical way in=
 Evolutionary Robotics/Algorithms (incl. novelty search, ie. an explicit fu=
nction formulating an implicit objective - though of course the search for =
novelty looks a lot like modelling the red queen). On the other hand, selec=
tion can result from environmental pressure as it is the case with TIERRA (=
and to less extent, to AVIDA, IMHO), where selection/replacement does not d=
epend on a performance value to be computed.
> 
> I agree with you both as =
AVIDA seems to stand inbetween as a performance measure is actually compute=
d (the metabolic function) but is not directly used for selection/replaceme=
nt. On the contraty, I always had the impression that TIERRA was something =
more on the side of "true" natural selection, environment-driven instead of=
 target-based. Of course, minimizing program size in TIERRA may be seen as =
the objective, but it is not explicitly formulated compared to AVIDA's meta=
bolic functions which directly impact the duplication success (if i am not =
mistaken, as i am not an AVIDA practitionner). 
> 
> In a recent paper co-a=
uthored with Jean-Marc Montanier (presented at the EPS workshop at ALIFE 20=
12), we summarized some work on environment-driven evolutionary adaptation =
of swarm of epucks robots done in the Symbrion swarm/modular robotic projec=
t, and we faced the problem as to where our own work stands. We came up wit=
h some sort of (imperfect) classification as we tried to position our own w=
ork wrt. traditional Evolutionary Robotics (ER), Embodied Evolution (EE), A=
LIFE simulation about evolution (ALIFE). I just extracted an up-to-date ima=
ge of the table from the paper so you may find it easily: check it here (ED=
EA is our own method, forget it if you wish, it is not the point here). Of =
course, this is not meant as a definitive table as frontiers are somewhat b=
lurred, as with the position of novelty search (which is also environment-d=
riven in some way, but still explicitly formulated) or AVIDA's metabolic fu=
nction (which also makes AVIDA task-driven). I'd be curious if some of you =
have some feedback to provide on this global classification.
> 
> Cheers,
>=
 
> Nicolas
> 
> ps:  btw, i really enjoyed reading your paper Jeff, inspir=
ing and clearly written, as always :-)
> 
>
